channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [HBASE-15816] Provide client with ability to set priority on Operations
item.description:
First round will just be to expose the ability to set priorities for client operations. For more background: http://mail-archives.apache.org/mod_mbox/hbase-dev/201604.mbox/%3CCA+RK=_BG_o=q8HMptcP2WauAinmEsL+15f3YEJuz=qbpcya5-g@mail.gmail.com%3E

Next step would be to remove AnnotationReadingPriorityFunction and have the client send priorities explicitly.
item.summary: Provide client with ability to set priority on Operations

status.description: A patch for this issue has been uploaded to JIRA by a contributor.

comments.comment:
Some assumptions were made,

When setting table priority and priority explicitly for a request, we take keep the Max priority for that request.

For batch operations, we apply the max priority for any operation for the entire batch.

-1 overall

I dont think that findbugs warning is related to this patch.
stack Would you mind reviewing when you have a chance? I didn't want to make a monster patch, so I'll create another patch for removing the annotation driven priorities. Thanks.

churro morales still interested in carrying this forward? I haven't heard much about this for a while. Is that because the problem to solve has been handled a different way or simply because I haven't been around much. /cc James Taylor

I looked at the v1 patch, it's fine, but...

I'll create another patch for removing the annotation driven priorities

This does make the reading of this patch "interesting", like the double setting of priority in HTable call implementations. Did you try this and indeed end up with a monster patch?

When removing annotation driven priorities we'll want unit tests that confirm where we're expecting QoS != NORMAL_QOS, the patch doesn't change behavior

I think it's fine to submit and review this as a sequence of patches but what should be committed is a single patch that addresses all relevant issues.

Andrew Purtell yes i am still interested in carrying it forward.

The patch for removing annotation driven priorities became quite large as I had to add that info to each protobuf message thus adding an optional priority field to each of those. That got to be a huge patch and thought I would gauge interest in this first patch before I finished the other patch. I can submit another patch along with this patch, or throw it up on the review board if that makes it easier for you guys.

I will add tests to confirm that the that the QOS != Normal for those annotated methods keeps the same behavior.

Thanks for taking a look and I assume there is some interest and that I should go ahead with the other patch for annotation driven priority removal.

Thanks for taking a look and I assume there is some interest and that I should go ahead with the other patch for annotation driven priority removal.

Yes
Thanks, churro morales! This is definitely an improvement and will allow Phoenix to clean some stuff up now that we can simply set the priority on the client-side.

What do you guys think about doing priorities at the HTD layer, rather than per-request: HBASE-16095. It will be a maintenance issue where in every use, the application has to make sure to set the priority correctly. It seems very fragile to keep the framework level code (like Phoenix) to ensure to set priorities in all cases.

I think Phoenix wants to set priorities per operation so that wouldn't be a good example of promoting to HTD. Correct me if I'm wrong. In general I'd like to have the option for implementing per op QoS if we're exposing anything like this at all.
What do you think about doing both? I like setting priorities on the table level, but it would also optionally be nice to set priorities on the operation level if I wanted to.

churro morales This is very cool!

My only challenge is in groking as an operator a misbehaved client or the pain of debugging SLA misses trying to use this. (Maybe not the feature for my perceived problem?) Would it be imprudent to add a JMX metric for priority requests per table (or region) so one could see if a client is asking for ADMIN_QOS on all their requests or some silliness?
churro morales are you still interested in pushing for this? The master has changed a bit and the patch needs a rebase. I can pick up the work if you have no cycles.

-1 overall
